title: Ticket #2054: hfs looping on "group quota exceeded"
description:
In old code, the cleanup of usage values and "pruning" of a group from further negotiation was done immediately after negotiation of that group. Part of this was setting a flag that would halt negotiation. And part of this was setting groupArray[i].numsubmits == 0, which would then hit 

if (  groupArray[i].numsubmits == 0  ) {
...
   continue;
   }

This would skip negotiation for this group in the next iteration. The group would be pruned from all subsequent negotiation. The flag was a defensive measure taken due to comparison of doubles. In new code, negotiation for all groups is done followed by a new loop that does the clean up. There is no flag and the groups are not pruned immediately.

Repro: 

NUM_CPUS = 100
GROUP_NAMES = a, b
GROUP_QUOTA_DYNAMIC_a = .4
GROUP_QUOTA_DYNAMIC_b = .6
GROUP_AUTOREGROUP_a = FALSE

The create a number of different users for group a.

Like 5 users ranging from a.a1 to a.a5. 

executable =./sleep.a1
arguments = 600
universe = vanilla
should_transfer_files = YES
when_to_transfer_output = ON_EXIT
+AccountingGroup = "a.a1"
queue 200

Let the jobs fill the 40 slots and then 

grep exceeded NegotiatorLog

04/05/11 11:56:55       Rejected 1444.8 a.a4@basin.redhat.com
<166.217.160.21:41826>: group quota exceeded
04/05/11 11:56:55       Rejected 1443.8 a.a3@basin.redhat.com
<166.217.160.21:41826>: group quota exceeded
04/05/11 11:56:55       Rejected 1442.8 a.a2@basin.redhat.com
<166.217.160.21:41826>: group quota exceeded
04/05/11 11:56:55       Rejected 1445.8 a.a5@basin.redhat.com
<166.217.160.21:41826>: group quota exceeded
04/05/11 11:56:56       Rejected 1441.7 a.a1@basin.redhat.com
<166.217.160.21:41826>: group quota exceeded

In scenarios with lots of users like 100, you will get 100 rejections for "group quota exceeded". These could all be pruned either before or immediately after the 1st rejection (the one for a.a4 in the example).
remarks:
2011-Apr-18 16:25:53 by danb:
Code review:

For a stable series patch, it would be better to refrain from so much cosmetic surgery. There are a number of changes in code flow, variable names, whitespace, comment style, variable declaration placement---all of which do not really seem fundamental to the patch.

That said, "submitterAds" is a much better name than "scheddAds" :).

I am concerned about the change in what happens when the submitter limit is reached. Previously, this resulted in result=MM_RESUME, which (if I understand things correctly), resulted in the submitter remaining in line for consideration in future spins of the pie. In the patch, this case is handled by removing the submitter from the list of submitters, so I think this means this user will not be considered in subsequent spins of the pie: 

            if (!ignore_submitter_limit && ((submitterLimit <= 0) || (pieLeft < minSlotWeight))) {
                // If limit is 0, and we are respecting submitter limits, don't waste time with negotiate
                negotiation_cycle_stats[0]->submitters_share_limit.insert(submitterName.Value());
                dprintf(D_FULLDEBUG, "Submitter %s is at its submitter limit %g\n", submitterName.Value(), submitterLimit);
                submitterAds.Remove(submitter);
                continue;
            }

In general, this seems like a pretty aggressive patch for a stable series. This makes it hard to be confident that no surprises are introduced. I'd recommend splitting this into two patches: one suitable for the stable series that fixes the problem with minimal code disturbance, and another with all the other improvements to the code.

2011-Apr-18 17:44:07 by eje:
Ouch, good catch -- shouldn't remove submitter on hitting submitter limit.

2011-Apr-25 14:02:42 by danb:
Looks good! I don't spot any problems in version 2 of the patch.

2011-Apr-26 11:55:27 by danb:
Erik, you committed the patch to the master branch. It should go into V7_6-branch, right?

Incidentally, one of the problems fixed in this patch should also fix #2092.

That was my typo -- I had intended v070700, since it was more of a convenience and efficiency improvement than fixing any incorrect behavior.

(however, I will be happy to backport it to 7.6 branch, if Greg is amenable)
